contextId.information: Possible interpretations: 1) Samson is so thirsty he could literally die. AT: "But now I will die of thirst and my body will fall" 2) Samson exaggerates how thirsty he is by asking if he will die of thirst. AT: "But now will you allow me to become so weak from my thirst that I fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: But now will I die of thirst and fall

contextId.information: The author used a hyperbole, an exaggeration, to emphasize how miserable Sampson felt. AT: "that he was completely miserable" or "that he was very unhappy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: that he wished he would die

contextId.information: Here "everything" refers to everything about the source of his strength. This can be stated clearly. AT: "told her the source of his strength" or "told her the truth" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

The men use a hyperbole, an exaggeration, to emphasize that it is a very desirable place to live. AT: "where we will have everything there that we need" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: that does not lack anything in the land

contextId.information: The Israelites are exaggerating. They had already given wives to four hundred of the Benjamites, so the tribe would not be completely destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: There must be an inheritance ... is not destroyed from Israel
